message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public class Test {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String str = "[00:25.30]";
        StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, ":[]", true);
        String hours = st.nextToken();
        st.nextToken(); // skip the delimiter
        String minutes = st.nextToken();
        st.nextToken(); // skip the delimiter
        String seconds = st.nextToken();

        int min = Integer.parseInt(minutes);
        min += 2; // add two minutes

        String newTime = "[" + hours + ":" + min + "." + seconds + "]";
        System.out.println(newTime);
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: The code uses StringTokenizer to split the string into hours, minutes, and seconds. It then parses the minutes as an integer, adds two to it, and constructs a new string with the updated minutes. The delimiters (the colon and brackets) are included in the tokens returned by StringTokenizer, so we need to call nextToken() to skip over them.
